boat.name: Jaunty

owners.note: Roy Marsden built her for himself and lived aboard on the Rivers Trent and Humber for 20 or so years until he died. She was sold to Mr Phoenix of Telford who sold her to Gary Taylor in 2002.
owners.text: Roy Marsden built her for himself and lived aboard on the Rivers Trent and Humber for

boat.full_description:
Jaunty's builder, Roy Marsden, took ten years to build her in the 1960s. he was a boatbuilder and cabinet maker. He lived aboard for 20 or so years until he died. Her stem and centre structure are seasoned oak with oak planking. Planking is carvel formed over oak frames 2.5" x 2". The mast is deck stepped in a tabernacle which allows it to be raised and lowered by one man (originally for bridges on the River Trent).

She was bought by David Pugh, 2006, in a neglected condition. He was a cabinet maker and the saloon abounds with his skills including brass drop down handles on drawers and a beautiful navigation station. She has two berths and a Baby Blake loo, double primus cooking stove and mahogany cockpit seats and surrounds.
boat.construction_details: Stem and centre structure in seasoned oak with oak, oak carvel planking over oak frames 2.5 x 2 inches and oak steamed timbers of 1.75 x 1 inch. Fastenings are copper
boat.short_description: Jaunty is a gentleman's yacht designed and built by Roy Marsden between 1960 and 1968 for estuary and river sailing.
